loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Adjata

texts.fr:
Madame Adjata B. a 52 ans, elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants (2 garçons et 2 filles) dans la grande famille traditionnelle à Fama, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Adjata B.  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,  s’est initiée à la fabrique des savons traditionnels (savons noirs) il y a maintenant quatre (04) ans qu’elle a appris auprès d’une voisine. Elle mène son activité dans son domicile de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée par sa clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de joindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant un (1) ans. Elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel, le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 4 fuits  des déchets d’huile de coton (pates noires) et 2 sacs de soude caustique. Après fabrication des savons à base de déchets d’huile de coton et de soude caustique, elle les revend en détail à une clientèe composée généralement des femmes de sa localité..
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Adjata B., age 52, resides with her husband and their children (two boys and two girls) in a large traditional family in Fama, Sikasso's downtown (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having done many kinds of work unsuccessfully, she got started in making traditional soaps (black soaps) four years ago with a neighbor who taught her. She works at home in Sikasso, where she is in high demand by her customers because of the quality of her products.

To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso a year ago and is on her second individual loan. The preceding loan has been correctly repaid. She plans to use this loan to buy four barrels of waste cotton oil (black paste) and two sacks of caustic soda. After making the soaps from the waste cotton oil and caustic soda, she sells them retail to customers composed generally of the women of her town.

With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for helping to cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in her work.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy waste cotton oil and caustic soda

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en: Idowu R. is 42 years old and married with three children. She sells provisions such as drinks, juice and local gin.  She needs a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Mademoiselle  Aminata T.  a 24 ans et réside chez ses parents avec ses cadets à Sanoubougou II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Mademoiselle  Aminata T. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente  d’habillements  et produits de beauté, de pagne( Wax HITARGET et REAL) de Gel de beauté, crèmes pour la peau, Mèches, parfums, savons de beauté, etc  il y a maintenant trois (03) ans. Elle vendait de façon ambulante avant d’ avoir sa propre place  “AMINA BEAUTE”. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clienèle ( composée essentiellement des jeunes filles de son quartier) pourr la qualité de ses produits. Vue le positionnement de sa place, son activité marche à merveille et la clientèle est très satisfaite.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’ intgrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois (03) mois et est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avant d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, Mademoiselle  Aminata T.  avait certaines difficultés pour mener à bien son activité à cause de la faiblesse de son fonds de roulement.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 10 pièces de pagnes Wax HITARGET, 10 pièces de pagne Wax REAL, 3 douzaines de Gel, 4 douzaines de crème pour Peau, 2 douzaine de Mèches et 2 cartons de de savons de beauté différentes.  Elle s’approvisionne à Bobo Dioulasso, Abidjan et Bamako (respectivement au Burkina Faso  et en  république de la Côte d‘Ivoire et du Mali en Afrique de l’ouest), ensuite elle les revend dans sa luxe beauté située à Sanoubougou II, Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt .
texts.en:
Ms. Aminata T., age 24, resides in the home of her parents with her younger brothers in Sanoubougou II, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having done many kinds of work unsuccessfully, she got started three years ago in buying and selling clothing, beauty products, "pagnes" (Wax HITARGET and REAL brands), Gel de Beauté, skin cream, hair extensions, perfumes, beauty soaps, etc. She used to sell door-to-door before obtaining her own place “AMINA BEAUTE”. Because of the quality of her products, she is in high demand, especially by her customers (composed essentially of the girls in her district). Due to her location, her business is doing superbly, and the customers are very satisfied.

Concerned about satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago and is on her first individual loan. Before joining the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, she had certain difficulties in carrying out her work because of her scant working capital. She plans to use this loan to buy 10 lengths of Wax HITARGET brand pagnes (colorful West African cloth), 10 lengths of Wax REAL brand pagnes, 3 dozen Gel, 4 dozen skin cream, 2 dozen hair extensions, and 2 boxes of different beauty soaps. She gets her supplies in Bobo Dioulasso, Abidjan and Bamako (respectively, in Burkina Faso, Côte d'Ivoire, and Mali in West Africa). And then she sells them retail in her luxury salon located in Sanoubougou II, Sikasso.

With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her business capital, to help with family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell fabrics, clothing, and beauty products

loans.name: Omowumi

texts.en: Omowumi B. is 31 years old and married with a child. She has been in the business of selling shoes and bags for more than 10 years. She hopes to own her own boutique in the future. She needs aloan amount of N50,000 to purchase additional shoes and bags to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders and Lapo microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Ejike James

texts.en: James Ejike O. is 41 years old and married with two children. He lives in Ibadan, Nigeria. He sells tires. He is currently a Lapo microfinance client. He needs a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase addtional tires to sell. He says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more tires to sell

loans.name: Saliu

texts.en: Saliu A. is 41-years-old and is married with five children. He sells an assortment of vegetables (carrots, green peas, cabbage, etc.) to retail customers. He purchases the vegetables wholesale and is requesting a loan amount of $350 (N50, 000) to purchase more vegetables to resell. He is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders and to Lapo microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi (composé de 7 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et 1 enfant. Elles résident dans le quartier  Bougoula Ville de la ville de Sikasso.
Elles  exercent les activités commerciales suivantes, vente de condiments, du savon et des légumes. 
Pour mener à bien leur activité et de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, ils sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Le prêt précédent s’est  bien dénoué.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 4 paniers de tomates, 8 sacs de 50 kg d’oignon et 12 cartons de savon. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso ville (3eme Région administrative du Mali) et dans les villages environnants.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans le quartier à domicile à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 19 000 FCFA par mois qu’elles utilisent pour soutenir un peu la famille en aidant leur mari et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkadi (composed of seven married women) average 28 years age and one child. They reside in the Bougoula Ville district of the city of Sikasso and do commerce in the following: condiments, soap, and vegetables. To carry out their work and to satisfy the needs of their customers, they are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loan was settled.

The group members plan to use this loan to buy four baskets of tomatoes, eight 50-kg sacks of onions, and twelve boxes of soap. They get their supplies locally in Sikasso City (third administrative region of Mali) and in surrounding villages. The goods are sold retail, mostly for cash, in the marketplaces of Sikasso (Médine and the grand marketplace) and from homes in the district. The customers are composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 19,000 francs CFA per month that they will use to support their families a little by helping their husbands and to invest the rest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soap, condiments, and vegetables

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi (composé de 4 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 24 ans avec en moyenne 1 enfant. Elles resident dans le quartier  Mancourani I de la ville de sikasso.
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente d’habits pour enfant menée par (2) clientes et à laquelle s’ajoute la vente de fruits et de chaussures.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêts précédents ont été correctement  remboursés.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 4 douzaines d’habits  pour enfant, un chargement d’orange et de mandarine et une vingtaine de paire de chaussures. Elles s’approvisionnent soit à Bamako capitale du Mali,  ou sur place à Sikasso et environnants.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 21.000 FCFA par mois qu’elles comptent utiliser, une partie dans les activités et l’autre partie aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkadi (composed of 4 married women) have an average age of 24 and on average one child. They live in the Mancourani I neighborhood of the town of Sikasso.

They each have different businesses, but the most common is selling children's clothing in which 2 clients are involved; ithe other two are in the businesses of selling fruit and vegetables and selling shoes.

They work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele. They are on their 4th solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy 4 dozen outfits for children, a load of oranges and mandarines, and around 20 pairs of shoes. They do their buying either in Bamako, the capital of Mali, or right in Sikasso and the surrounding area.

The items are sold retail and on a cash basis in the markets of the town of Sikasso (Médine and the big open-air market) and in their own neighborhoods, to a clientele composed of men and women.

They each hope to make an average profit 21,000 FCFA a month that they plan to use partially for their businesses and partially for the needs of their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy outfits for children, fruit, and shoes for their businesses

loans.name: Adisa

texts.en:
Adisa T. sells plank (lumber) at the Songo plank market in Ibadan, Nigeria. The demands for his plank are high. He has been in this business for a long time and has an established customer base. Adisa hopes to expand this business and is requesting a loan amount of $425 (N60,000) to purchase more plank to sell.

He is 54-years-old and is married with four children. He hopes to send his children to school for a quality education. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more plank to sell

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en:
Marhabo H. is 47 and married with three children. Since she has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle and also breeding sheep. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy cattle at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. She currently has 2 cows, a calf, and 4 sheep which she will fatten for some time to later sell them.

With the loan she wants to buy feed for her animals. In future she is planning to save capital to open a store in her home, because she is afraid that because of her age, in the future she will not be able to work buying and selling animals.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing feed for animals

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac A. sells plank (lumber) at the Songo plank market, Ibadan, Nigeria. He has been in this business for a long time. He hopes to expand this business and is requesting a loan amount of $425 (N60,000) to purchase more plank to sell. He is 46-years-old and is married with three children. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more plank to sell

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
Munavvar is a responsible and loving mother who is always thinking of the well-being and security of her children. She is dedicated to raising cows and sheep. While she is exerting herself in this, her husband leaves very early in the morning and travels great distances to provide veterinary services to peasants in need of care for their animals. The hope of this responsible mother is to purchase more animals to expand their business. To reach this goal they are requesting a loan of 600 USD, which they plan to repay in 8 months.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing  cattle in order to expand her business

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya (composé de 4 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 27 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Babemba de la ville de sikasso.
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes, vente de condiments, du bois de chauffe, des chaussures et des pagnes wax et real.
Elles collaborent avec  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  pour satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêt précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 8 chargements de charrette de en bois de chauffe, 5 pièces de pagnes wax et real, une vingtaine de chaussures en plastique et 3colis de condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent  sur place à Sikasso et environnants.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans quartier à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 12 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt,subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group (composed of 4 married women) have an average age of 27 and on average, 3 children. They live in the Babemba neighborhood of the town of Sikasso.

They have varied commercial ventures: selling condiments, firewood, shoes, and "wax" and "real" African print cloth.

They collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their clientele. They are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy 8 wagonloads of firewood, 5 lengths of wax or real African print cloth, some 20 pairs of plastic shoes and 3 bales of condiments. They do their buying right in Sikasso and its surroundings.

The items are sold retail and mostly on a cash basis in the markets of the town of Sikasso (Médine and the big open-air market of the town) and in their own neighborhoods to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each hope to make an average profit of 12,000 FCFA a month which will be used to make repayments on the loan and cover the needs of their families, re-investing any remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments, firewood, shoes and lengths of African print cloth

loans.name: Timothy

texts.en: Timothy Ogeniyi sells clothes and shoes. His shop is open daily from 7AM-6:30PM. He hopes to expand his business and is requesting a loan amount of $675 (N100,000) to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible. He is a LAPO client.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Lukman

texts.en: Lukman A. is 40-years-old and is married with three children. He sells yams both wholesale and retail to his customers in the Ayeye market, Ibadan, Nigeria. Yams are a major food commodity in Nigeria. The demand for his yams are high and he hopes to meet those demands by requesting a loan of $675 (N100,000) to purchase more of them to sell. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Jiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Jiguiya (composé de 6 femmes  mariées) ont en moyenne 38 ans et 4 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Mancourani de la ville de Sikasso.
Elles  exercent les activités commerciales telle l’achat vente des condiments alimentaires, de tubercules et de fruits.
 Pour mener à bien leur activité et de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, ils sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêt précédents se sont correctement  dénoué.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 5 paniers de tomate 8sacs de 50kg d’oignon 5 sacs de sacs de pommes de terre. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso ville  et les villages environnants auprès des paysans producteurs.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et  au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso  et dans le quartier à domicile à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20 000 FCFA par mois qu’elles utilisent pour soutenir un peu la famille en aidant leur mari et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Jiguiya group (composed of 6 married women) have an average age of 38 and four children, on average. They live in the Mancourani neighborhood of the town of Sikasso.

They have commercial businesses such as buying and selling condiments, yams, and fruit. So as to conduct their businesses appropriately and satisfy the needs of their clientele, they collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

They intend to use this loan to buy 5 baskets of tomatoes, 8 sacks of 50 kg of onions, and 5 sacks of potatoes. They do their buying right in Sikasso and the surrounding villages, from the farmers who produce the foodstuffs. The items are sold retail and for cash in the markets of the town of Sikasso and their own neighborhoods, out of their homes, to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each hope to make an average profit of 20,000 FCFA per month which they will use to help their husbands support their families, re-investing any remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing condiments, fruit, and yams

loans.name: Rahima

texts.en:
Rahima D. is 43 years old. She is married and has three children. Her family lives in Kanibadam, Northern Tajikistan. Rahima sells clothes for children in the central city market. The location of her vending store is very favorable as it’s in a busy place. Rahima has been in this trade for many years. She has proven to be an honest and communicative businesswoman. Rahima is hoping to make a loan of $ 1200 USD to increase the variety of inventory in her store and keep her business running successfully. She promises to fulfill the loan term within 9 months. This purchase will enable her to increase her sales, to earn more, and to meet the education expenses of her children.

loans.use: Increase the working capital to develop the business.

loans.name: Temitope

texts.en: Temitope S. is 33-years-old and is married with three children. She is a hair dresser and she also sells beverages. She creates lovely hair styles for her many customers. Temitope is requesting a loan of $675 (N100,000) to purchase one deep freezer, additional beverages and hair extensions. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase one deep freezer, beverages and hair extensions

loans.name: Murod

texts.en:
Murod I. has always been a hard-working man. He has made sure, from his young age, that his family never goes without their daily bread. He is married with three children. Murod has a grocery store where he sells various kinds of food products. With a starting capital of 500 USD, he began this enterprise 5 years ago. With thanks to his perseverance and dedication his business expanded, and today the business employs his daughter (pictured), son and wife. Today he needs to buy additional food items to increase the variety of the goods that he sells. For this purpose, he is requesting a loan of $ 600 USD for the term of 6 months. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal of becoming a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors with his small business.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase additional food products to increase the variety of products sold

loans.name: Djougousomperin Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djougousomperin (composé de 5 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  hamdallaye de la ville de Sikasso.
Elles  vendent divers  produits mais la plus dominante est la vente de pomme de terre à laquelle s’ajoutent la vente de tasses et  celle du bois de chauffe.
Les femmes de ce groupe collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle de plus en plus croissante. Elles sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent acheter  avec ce prêt 4 sacs de 100kg de pomme de terre, 2 chargements de camionnette en bois de chauffe et 3 douzaines de tasses métalliques et en plastique. Elles s’approvisionnent soit à Bamako (capitale du Mali), ou sur place à Sikasso et dans les villages environnants.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et  au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso et  dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 27.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Djougousomperin (composed of five married women) average 33 years of age and three children. They reside in the Hamdallaye district of the city of Sikasso and commerce in various goods, but the predominant work is the sale of potatoes, plus bowls, tubs, and firewood.

The women of the group are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy their burgeoning customer base. They are on their tenth solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding ones have been correctly repaid. They plan to use this loan to buy four 100-kg sacks of potatoes, two truck-loads of firewood, and three dozen metal and plastic tubs. They get their supplies either in Bamako (capital of Mali) or locally in Sikasso and surrounding villages. The goods are sold at the retail level for cash, in the marketplaces of Sikasso and in the districts, to customers composed of women and men.

They each hope to realize an average profit of 27,000 francs CFA a month that will be used to pay the loan interest and to invest the rest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tubs, firewood, and potatoes

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah O. bakes and sells loaves of bread at the wholesale and retail levels. The demand for his loaves of bread is high and he hopes to meet those demands by expanding his business. He is requesting a loan of $675 (N100,000) to purchase more raw ingredients for baking additional loaves of bread for resale. Elijah has owned this business for a long time and has established customers.

Elijah is 35-years-old and is married with one child. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more raw ingredients for baking bread to sell wholesale and retail

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Folake O.,43, is a LAPO client. She is married with two children and lives in Eleyele, Ibadan, Nigeria. She sells shoes and bags, and hopes to own her own boutique in the future. She is requesting a loan amount of $675 (N100,000) to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Princess

texts.en: Princess O. is 54-years-old and is married with six children. She sells clothes and is also a fashion designer. She creates lovely designs for her customers. The demand for her clothing is high. Princess is requesting a loan of $675 (N100,000) to purchase more clothes to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders and LAPO microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Kotognogontala (composé de 4 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Médine de la ville de sikasso.
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes respectivement : la vente de bananes, de bazin, d’habits pour enfant et de chaussures.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle de plus en plus croissante. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 4 douzaines de vêtement  pour enfants, une dizaine de régime de banane, une quinzaine de paire de chaussures et 25m de tissu bazin. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso et environnants 
Les produits sont vendus en détail et  au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (surtout au marché de Médine et au grand marché de la ville) et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 17.500 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Kotognogontala (composed of four married women) average 28 years of age and three children. They reside in the Médine district of the city of Sikasso and do commerce variously in: bananas, damask fabrics, children’s clothing, and shoes.

They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy their burgeoning customer base and are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loan has been correctly repaid. They plan to use this loan to buy 4 dozen pieces of children’s clothing, a dozen bunches of bananas, 15 pairs of shoes, and 25 meters of damask. Their supplies are gotten locally in Sikasso and surrounding areas.

The goods are sold at the retail level and for cash in the marketplaces of Sikasso (especially in the Médine marketplace and the grand marketplace of the city) and in the districts, to customers composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 17,500 francs CFA per month that will be used to provide for the family and to invest the rest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's clothing, bananas, shoes, and cloth

loans.name: Yetunde

texts.en: Yetunde A. is 39-years-old and is married with four children. Yetunde rents chairs and tables to customers for social ceremonies like birthday parties, wedding ceremonies and burial ceremonies. Yetunde also does interior party decorations. She is requesting a loan of $675 (N100,000) to purchase more chairs, tables and decorating materials. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more chairs, tables and decorating materials

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sabali (composé de 5 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 33ans avec en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles resident dans le quartier  Ouayerma I dans la ville de sikasso.
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes telles que l’achat vente des chaussures, du bois de chauffe, du bazin, des tasses et seaux en plastique.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle de plus en plus croissante les membres de ce groupe ont  intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, il y a 3 ans. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Tous les prêts  précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 4 douzaines de chaussures, 10 chargements de bois de chauffe, 1 trentaine d’habits  pour enfant, 1 dizaine de pagnes et bazin (de 5 mètres bien teintés) et 1cinquantaine de tasses et seaux en plastique. 
Elles s’approvisionnent soit en Côte D’ivoire pays frontalier du Mali soit à Bamako (capitale du Mali),  ou sur place à Sikasso.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans le quartier à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 27 500 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sabali are composed of five married women who average 33 years of age and two children. They reside in the Ouayerma I district in the city of Sikasso and do commerce, such as in: shoes, firewood, damask fabrics, basins, and plastic buckets.

To satisfy their burgeoning customer base, the group members have joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago and are on their fifth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. They plan to use this loan to buy 4 dozen shoes, 10 loads of firewood, 30 children’s outfits, a dozen “pagnes” (colorful West African cloth) and damask fabrics (five meters, well-dyed), and 50 plastic tubs and buckets. Their supplies are gotten either in Cote d’Ivoire, which is a nation bordering Mali, or in Bamako (capital of Mali), or locally in Sikasso.

The goods are sold at the retail level and mostly for cash in the marketplaces of Sikasso (Médine marketplace and the grand marketplace of the city) and in the district, to customers composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 27,500 francs CFA per month that will be used to provide for the family and to invest the rest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Lolo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Lolo (composé de 5 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans avec en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Babemba de la ville de sikasso.
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais les plus dominantes sont respectivement la vente de condiments alimentaires, de pagnes wax - real  et des savons.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 8 pièces de pagnes wax et real, 3 sacs de 100kg de savons traditionnels (gros morceaux) et  3 paquets de condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent  sur place à Sikasso et environnants.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et  au comptant  au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 17 000 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Lolo (composed of 5 married women) have an average age of 32 and on average, 4 children. They live in the Babemba neighborhood of the town of Sikasso.

They have varied commercial activities, most prevalent being the sale of condiments, of African print cloth, and of soap. They collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their clientele. They are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan they intend to buy 8 lengths of African print cloth ("wax" and "real" types), 3 sacks of 100 kg of traditional soap (in large chunks), and 3 bundles of condiments. They do their buying right in Sikasso and its environs. The items are sold retail and for cash in the big open-air market of Sikasso and in their neighborhoods, to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each hope to make an average profit of 17,000 FCFA per month of which part will be used to cover family needs, investing the remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy condiments, soap, and African print cloth

loans.name: Paskazia

texts.en: Paskazia V. is a Tanzanian woman. She runs a shop at Buza ward in Dar es Salaam. She is married with four school children. She sells a varieties of commodities, which she purchases from the wholesale shops scattered around the city and sometimes directly from the producers. She plans to run a wholesale shop, but funding is a problem. Paskazia V. is requesting a loan of T.shs 600,000 ($450.00) to help her develop this business.

loans.use: Buy additional stock

loans.name: Jema

texts.en: Jema A. is a Tanzanian micro entrepreneur. She runs a retail shop at Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam. Shop businesses are very common in Tanzania due to the nature of commodities sold to customers. A. sells a variety of commodities in her shop, including seal crop products. She needs a loan of Tshs 600,000 ($450) to grow her business.

loans.use: Purchase more stock

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en: Zainabu M. is a Tanzanian business woman. She runs a business selling traditional clothes (Vitenge and Kanga) at Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the clothing from Mnazi mmoja traditional clothes shopping center and resells them to customers from her retail shop. She has been running this business for six years. Zainabu M. plans to run a wholesale shop. She is requesting a loan of Tshs. 600,000. ($450) to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en: Rukia N. is an entrepreneurial Tanzanian woman. She runs a shop at Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam, which are very common in Tanzania. Rukia sells a variety of items in her shop, including serial crop products, which are very common and in high demand. Items like maize flower, wheat flower, sugar, groundnuts, cashew nuts, and cooking oil are consumed by customers on a daily basis. Rukia N. is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000. ($600) to buy additional stock.

loans.use: Buy additional stock to sell

loans.name: Águeda

texts.es: Águeda tiene 42 años, vive en una casa alquilada, es viuda, tiene un hijo de 17 años llamado Diego. Bajo el intenso calor de la ciudad de Puno, Águeda se gana la vida refrescando a las personas con sus ricos helados, quienes no dejan de degustar los sabores tan sabrosos y novedosos que ella prepara para sus largos días de trabajo, pero quien más saborea estos helados es su hijo Diego, el cual le ayuda a prepararlos y aprovecha de vez en cuando para saborear uno. Águeda disfruta de servir helados a los niños que se le acercan a comprarle, porque siente que con sus helados les da un momento de felicidad y refresco y aunque le va muy bien, no falta un día nublado y frió donde sus ventas no son las esperadas, lo cual le molesta mucho. Águeda se encuentra en segundo préstamo, tiene la seguridad de pagar sus cuotas puntualmente, tal como lo hizo con el primero. Con el dinero que está solicitando quiere implementar más su propio negocio de helados y distribuir, comprará carritos y los equipos necesarios para su elaboración en grandes cantidades.
texts.en:
Águeda is 42 years old, lives in a rented house, is a widow, and has one 17-year old son named Diego. Under the intense heat of the city of Puno, Águeda earns her living refreshing the public with her delicious ice creams creating delicious and novel flavors for her long workdays. Who most enjoys them is her son Diego, who helps her prepare them and treats himself to one occasionally. Águeda enjoys selling her product to the children who approach her, since she feels they provide a moment of happiness and refreshment. Despite the fact that all goes well for her, she does experience cloudy and cold days when her sales drop, which troubles her. Águeda is in her second loan, and is sure of making her payments on time, as she did for her first loan. With the funds she is requesting, she would like to make improvements to her business and distributing her products. She will buy carts and the equipment necessary to make her product in large quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase tools for making ice creams.

loans.name: Ayde

texts.es: En su casa alquilada, Ayde de 19 años, compra toda la chatarra que puede para luego venderla, es soltera así que trabaja sola. Rodeada de artefactos viejos, los cuales espera vender, Ayde comienza su día en la “cachina” (mercado de cosas usadas), ofrece diversos artículos a las personas que pasan, pero disfruta más cuando logra venderlas y es que su alegría hace que sea una de las mejores vendedoras de la cachina. Ayde sufre mucho trasladando la pesada chatarra hasta su negocio, pero aun así, ya lleva un año sacrificándose para mejorar su futuro. Como Ayde pudo pagar con mucha facilidad su primer préstamo con MFP, decidió solicitar este segundo crédito que sabe también pagara a tiempo. Con la cantidad requerida comprará más chatarra, para tener más cosas que ofrecer a la gente que compra en la cachina.
texts.en:
From her rented house, Ayde, 19 years old, buys all the scraps she can to later sell. She is single, and therefore works on her own. Surrounded by old artifacts which she hopes to sell, Ayde starts her day at the “cachina” (used goods market) offering her various items to passersby. She enjoys it the most when she manages to sell something, and her happiness makes her one of the best salespeople at the cachina. Ayde suffers a great deal transporting her second-hand wares to her place of business and, despite this hardship, she has spent a year so far sacrificing to improve her future. Since Ayde was easily able to repay her first loan with MFP, she decided to request this second loan that she knows she will also pay back on time. With the amount she is requesting, she will buy more used goods to have more to offer the people who come to buy at the cachina.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise.

loans.name: Erika

texts.es: Erika de 33 años, vive con sus dos hijos; Araceli de 11 años y Alexis de 5, en su casa propia, donde alista la lencería para llevarla a vender. En Puno, si la gente quiere vestir la lencería más bonita, inevitablemente tiene que ir al puesto de Erika, la vendedora más amistosa de ropa, quien ya tiene 10 años vistiendo a los muchos clientes que tiene. Su negocio es uno de los más rentables, debido a las novedades que constantemente pone a la venta, le alegra el día ver que uno de sus productos es del agrado del cliente y siente que lo más difícil de su negocio, es trasladar su mercadería, ya que no tiene quien la ayude, puesto que sus hijos están estudiando. Siendo este su segundo préstamo con MFP, Erika planea pagar a tiempo sus cuotas como es su costumbre. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería, para ampliar su negocio y satisfacer a una mayor cantidad de clientes.
texts.en:
Erika is 33 years old and lives with her two children, Araceli who is 11 and Alexis, 5 years old. She has her own house, where she gets ready to take her products to sell. In Puno, if someone wants the nicest undergarments, they inevitably must visit Erika’s stand. She is the friendliest of salespeople, who already has ten years tending to customers. Her business is one of the most profitable because of the novelties she is always offering for sale. It makes her day when one of her products satisfies a customer, and she feels one of the most difficult aspects of her business is transporting her products since she does not have any help as her children are in school. Being her second loan with MFP, Erika plans to make her loan installment payments on time as she has before. With the funds requested, she will purchase more merchandise to expand her business and satisfy a greater number of customers.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es: Gladys, de 21 años, es soltera y vive en una casa alquilada hecha de adobe. Con hasta 3 celulares en mano, Gladys trabaja todos los días para mejorar su futuro, ofreciendo llamadas a celulares de forma ambulatoria, la gente que pasa siempre la reconoce por el chalequito verde que acostumbra vestir y le solicitan realizar una llamada. Lleva ya 2 años en este negocio, el cual le da muchas satisfacciones porque es una de las más solicitadas, además disfruta mucho ayudando a la gente a comunicarse, pero lo que le resulta molesto y difícil es estar pendiente y con los ojos bien abiertos de cualquier peligro que pueda surgir, como el robo de alguno de sus equipos, debido a que trabajar en la vía pública es riesgoso. Gladys se encuentra en su segundo préstamo con MFP, y tiene la fe de poder adquirir otro más, al terminar el ciclo de este, para abrir un centro de llamadas. Con el dinero solicitado planea comprar otro celular, con el cual podrá satisfacer a más clientes.
texts.en:
Gladys is 21 years old, single and lives in a rented adobe house. Gladys has 3 cell phones and works in the street every day to improve her future offering calls to mobile phones. People passing by recognize her because of her green vest and they ask her to make a call for them. She has been doing this for 2 years and it is very satisfying as she is one of the most popular ones. She enjoys very much helping people to communicate, but it is annoying and difficult to have to pay attention to any danger that might occur such as theft of her phones as it is risky to work in the street. This is Gladys' second loan with MFP and she is confident that she will obtain another one when this has been repaid in order to set up a call center. With the requested loan she plans to buy another cell phone so she can get more clients.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a cell phone.

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a widow with two children. She lives in the town of Novaya Kahovka. Tatyana owns a little store and sells clothing in the local market. She has been in this trade for over seven years. Currently, Tatyana has 40,000 Grivnas in inventory. Her monthly income is about 2,000 – 3,000 Grivnas.  

Tatyana’s life motto is simple: “Integrity and treating people exactly as you would like to be treated.” Probably this is why she has succeeded in her business. However, Tatyana doesn’t want to stop at this stage. She wants to move on and focus her energy on growing and expanding, either by introducing new products or by increasing her sales area. That is why she is requesting this loan of 5,000 Grivnas and is hoping to repay it in eight months. Tatyana has a strong personality. She lost her husband two years ago and faced serious challenges in her business. However, she has recovered with the help of her son, who helped her out financially.

loans.use: To increase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en: Theresia S. is an entrepreneurial Tanzanian woman. She is a poultry keeper at Makangarawe Ward in Dar es Salaam. She raises poultry for both cooking and for laying eggs. Her poultry produces ten trails of eggs per day. She sells eggs to retailers for domestic use and to cafes and restaurants. She requests a loan of Tshs 800,000. ($600) to construct more poultry cages.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: Kehinde O. is 44-years-old and is married with six children. She sells goats, and with her increasing customer base, she is requesting a loan of $675 (N100,000) to purchase more goats and increase her sales. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO.

loans.use: To purchase more  goats to sell

loans.name: Katerina

texts.en:
Katerina B. is a widow who lives in Belaya Tserkov. She owns a small vending container-store in the central market of Fastov, a neighboring town about 30 kilometers away from Belaya Tserkov. Katerina has been in the clothing sales business for ten years. Experience, personal characteristics, and financial assistance have promoted stable expansion of Katerina’s venture. Presently, she has about 60,000 Grivnas invested in turnover capital. Minimum income is about 5,000 Grivnas a month.

Katerina is seeking to have a business which would provide her with stable income. She knows she doesn’t have another source of income as her husband passed away and she earns her own living. Katerina is responsible and hard-working. She never sits idle and loves busy days. Today she is requesting a loan of 3,000 Grivnas to purchase additional clothing for her inventory. Katerina is hoping to repay the current loan in 2 months.

This is a short-term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Bukola

texts.en: Bukola J., 37, lives in Ilogbo, Lagos state, Nigeria and has three children. She has been in the business of selling under garments, notebooks and school materials for quite a long time. Bukola hopes to expand her business by adding the grinding of cereals, millet, etc. to her product offerings. She is requesting a loan amount of $350 (N50,000) to purchase a grinding machine. She thanks those who loan money to help her succeed. She is a LAPO client.

loans.use: To purchase one grinding machine

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is a widow. She runs a small outdoor market business selling groceries in the central marketplace of her small town of Korolyovo. Mariya launched the small enterprise 8 years ago. Her business started really small. However, it has grown to 30,000 Grivnas in working capital and about 4,000 Grivnas in income each month. Mariya believes growth was possible due to additional lending services she received through Nadiya Ukraine.

Mariya is very focused and determined. She is grateful for all previous loans she has received which have helped the expansion of her business. Today Mariya is requesting a loan of 6,000 Grivnas so that she can re-supply her inventory and purchase additional food items which she can get at wholesale prices. The loan will be beneficial for Mariya’s business by keeping it competitive and promoting further growth so that it will continue to provide necessary income for her which is especially critical in this atmosphere of economic recession in Ukraine.

loans.use: To increase assortment of inventory

loans.name: Ladi

texts.en: Ladi J. is 39 years old and married with 5 children. She sells smoked fish. With her previous Kiva loan, she was able to increase her sales and make more profit. She is requesting the loan amount of N 150,000 to purchase more fish for sale. She says thanks to all who lend to her and to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for sale

loans.name: Fuerza Divina Group

texts.en:
Martina J. is the bank coordinator for the Bank of Hope "Fuerza Divina", which has 9 groups of 5 members each. Three groups are participating in this loan. Martina has 3 children, ages 29, 2 and 3. Martina sells all kinds of clothes in Hato Mayor.

Martina has received four loans from Esperanza; this would be her fifth. The first loans made it possible for her to expand her business. Her monthly sales have increased, so she needs this loan to replenish her business and be able to have more stock to offer her growing clientele. Martina hopes that she one day will be able to buy a nice house to live in and a place where she can set up her own clothing store.

With your help, Martina will be one step closer to accomplishing her dreams. Thank you for supporting this loan!

loans.use: replenish clothing business

loans.name: Rachida

texts.fr: Yerima rachida est une demoiselle très travailleuse qui réside dans le quartier d’awatamé, elle a ouvert une boutique qu’elle a appelé « AKPAKI & FILS », dans cette boutique elle fait le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale et divers, elle n’a jamais sollicité de crédits chez wages et sollicite donc son premier crédit d’un montant de 500000F pour réapprovisionner son stock de produits d’alimentation générale, elle va s’approvisionner dans le grand marché de lomé. Elle aide beaucoup sa famille avec le revenu de son travail.
texts.en:
Miss Rachida Yerima is a very hard-working young woman who lives in the Awatamé neighborhood where she has opened a little store that she calls «AKPAKI & FILS ». In this little store she sells general merchandise. She has never asked WAGES for a loan before and so is requesting her first loan in the amount of 500,000 F to replenish her inventory of foodstuffs. She will do her buying in the big market of Lomé. She helps her family a great deal with the income from her work.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs for re-sale

loans.name: Ebere

texts.en: Ebere O. sells second-hand clothes. The demand for her second-hand clothes is high. Ebere is 31 years old and married with 5 children. Ebere is a LAPO client. Ebere needs the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more second-hand clothes to sell. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Beny Group

texts.en:
Manix Lukeba is 38 years old. He is single with a nine year-old boy.  Apart from his son, Manix takes also care of two abandoned boys and a girl between the ages of 5 and 15. All of them attend school. Manix started his first business in 1995 as a money changer. His starting capital was $120 and he worked outdoors until 1999 when his monthly income allowed him to move his business indoors. He worked very hard and his business prospered. In 2001, his business working capital reached $1500. Unfortunately, he lost all of this money when thieves broke into his place of business and stole it.  Due to this traumatic event, Manix closed his business. He and his children went through a hard time as he had neither a job nor any income to support them financially. 

In 2002, Manix borrowed $200 from one of his best customers to re-launch his business. He re-launched it outdoors until August 2008 when he joined one of Hope’s groups named "Beny".  Manix used the first loan he received from Hope last September to diversify his business. He added another type of business selling cellular phones. With the second loan he received from Hope, he reinforced his working capital. Currently, his business capital is equivalent to $700. His business makes about $200 of profit per month. Manix likes this business because it is profitable and it helps him become economically stable, especially concerning food, housing, electricity and water bills and school fees for his children. 

Manix’s business requires honesty and patience to keep his permanent customers. He is glad to join Hope’s group because he hopes to enhance his business with Hope's loans. With the next loan from Hope, Manix is planning to move his business indoors in order to avoid the heavy rains during the rainy season and the strong sun. Manix sells in the most populated area located in the North Eastern area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To reinforce his working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed K. runs a charcoal store at Kisiwani in Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. He is married with three school children. He purchases charcoal wholesale direct from the charcoal maker in a nearby district and resells it to retailers for domestic use. He has been in this business for four years. Charcoal is the main source of power in most developing countries due to the high prices of electricity, which, besides being expensive, is also unstable. Mohamed K. needs a loan of Tshs 600,000. ($450) to buy more charcoal for resale.

loans.use: Buy more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria F. sells bags of charcoal in her shop in Tedi, Lagos, Nigeria. Victoria is determined to expand her business by adding the sale of yams. Victoria is 34 years old and married with 5 children. She is a LAPO client. Victoria needs the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more bags of charcoal and yams to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal and yams to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier de yokoe  à adidogomé, elle a pour activité le commerce de bissap et de fruits de baobab qui sont des fruits qu'on utilise pour faire du jus de bissaps et de jus de fruits de baobab, son activité marche bien. Elle a besoin d’acheter des fruits pour augmenter son stock, elle n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de chez wages et sollicite son premier crédit d’un montant de 300000F pour pouvoir acheter des bissaps et des fruits de baobab. Elle est mariée et a 04 enfants, ce crédit lui aussi permettra de soutenir sa famille.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Yokoe neighborhood in Adidogomé. Her business is selling "bissap" (hibiscus flowers) and monkey bread (baobab tree fruit), both of which are used in the preparation of juice. Her business is going well. She needs to buy more fruit to complete her stock. She has never before had a loan from WAGES, so she is requesting her first in the amount of 300,000 F to buy hibiscus flowers and monkey bread. She is married and has 4 children; this loan will allow her to better support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of hibiscus flowers and monkey bread

loans.name: Efe

texts.en: Efe a 45 years old and married with 5 children. She sells provisions. She needs a loan in the amount of N80, 000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Hawa

texts.fr:
Madame Hawa K. a 34 ans, elle réside avec son époux et leurs deux (2) enfants (2 garçons) à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Hawa K. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et vente du boid de chauffe et  de la  friperie il y a maintenant cinq (05) ans. Elle mène son activité à son domicile et de façon ambulante dans la ville de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux (02) mois avec laquelle elle est à son 1er prêt individuel.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 10 pièces de pagnes Wax, et 1 chargement  de camion de bois de chauffe. Elle achète les bois de chauffe dans les localittés environnantes de Sikasso et les pagnes Wax à  Bamako et à Bobo Dioulasso (respectivement au Mali et au Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre en détail.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 110 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hawa K., 34, resides with her husband and their two children (two sons) in Hamdallaye, one of the populous neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mrs. Hawa K., after having tried a lot of businesses without success, got into selling firewood and used clothing, 5 years ago. She runs her business out of her home and door-to-door in the town of Sikasso where she is much appreciated by her clientele due to the quality of her products. In order to satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two months ago, and she is on her first individual loan.

With this loan she intends to buy 10 lengths of African wax print cloth and one truckload of firewood. She buys the firewood in localities around Sikasso and the fabric in Bamako and Bobo Dioulasso ( in Mali and in Burkina Faso, respectively) and sells it retail.

With this loan, she expects to earn a monthly profit of 110,000 FCFA, which will be used essentially to bolster her working capital, to contribute to family expenses, and to make repayments on the loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of wax prints and firewood

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter M. is an enterprising Tanzanian man. He runs a shop at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. He sells a variety of items, including serial crop products. He plans to open a wholesale shop to increase his income. Small shops are very common and important in Tanzania because they provide the items that people demand on a daily basis. Peter M. is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000. ($750) to buy products for his new shop.

loans.use: Buy products for his new shop

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy F. is 45 years old. She is married with 5 children.

Dorothy sells provisions and foodstuffs like rice, beans, plantains, and yams. She has been in this business for a long time. The demand for her foodstuffs is high in her community; she hopes to be able to meet the demands of her customers.

Dorothy is an LAPO client. She needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is grateful to all kiva lenders and to LAPO microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Djitré

texts.fr: Cette dame réside dans le quartier d’avédji elavagnon, elle fait le commerce de charbons de bois, elle vend en détail et en gros, elle fait ce commerce depuis 1994, elle a besoin de nouveaux stocks de marchandises c’est pour cela qu’elle a sollicité auprès de WAGES un crédit de 500000 pour acheter des sacs de charbons de bois. Elle est mariée et à 03 enfants , son mari est un chauffeur.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Avédji Elavagnon neighborhood. She sells charcoal retail and also wholesale. She has been in this business since 1994. She needs to replenish her inventory and for that reason she has requested from WAGES a loan in the amount of 500,000 F to buy sacks of charcoal. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a chauffeur.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana M. sells tailoring materials like thread, needles and landings. She has been in this business for a long time. Now, Juliana needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She would like to grow her bsuiness.

Juliana is 44 years old. She is married with 5 children. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Bolale

texts.en:
Bolale is 45 years old. She is a widow who cares for 6 children.

Bolale sells jewelry and cosmetics in her shop. She has been in this business for many years.

She is a client of LAPO. Bolale hopes for a loan of N80,000 to purchase more jewelry and cosmetics to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders and to LAPO microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelry and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Paraiso Norte Group

texts.es: LAS  SOCIAS QUIENES CONFORMAN EL GRUPO " PARAÍSO NORTE" SON PERSONAS QUE SE CONOCEN DE MUCHO TIEMPO YA QUE RESIDEN EN EL MISMOS, ESTÁN REPRESENTADAS POR LA SEÑORA ESTELA QUIEN ES LA PRESIDENTA DEL GRUPO. EN SU MAYORÍAS LOS SOCIOS (AS ) SE DEDICAN A PEQUEÑOS NEGOCIOS DE VENTA DE PRODUCTOS COMO ROPA, COSMÉTICOS, COMIDA, BEBIDAS Y A ACTIVIDADES DE SERVICIOS COMO CONSTRUCTORES, COCINERAS Y TÉCNICOS EN REPARACIÓN ELÉCTRICA. DENTRO DEL ÁMBITO COMERCIAL Y DE SERVICIOS EXISTE LA COMPETENCIA FUERTE DE LA OFERTA Y LA DEMANDA, PERO LA EXPERIENCIA DE LOS SOCIOS Y LOS AÑOS DE SERVICIO HACEN QUE SEA MAS LLEVADERA. EL FINANCIAMIENTO ESTA DESTINADO A LA COMPRA DE MATERIALES Y HERRAMIENTAS DE TRABAJO PARA BRINDAR UN MEJOR PRODUCTO Y UN MEJOR SERVICIO ACORDE A LA DEMANDA DEL MERCADO. LOS SOCIOS (AS) SE SIENTEN CAPACES DE ADMINISTRAR LOS FONDOS OTORGADOS YA QUE CUENTAN CON EXPERIENCIA EN GRUPOS SOLIDARIOS Y SABEN RESPONDER Y CUMPLIR CON SUS OBLIGACIONES YA QUE SON GENTE CON GANAS DE MEJORAR SU CALIDAD DE VIDA Y LA DE SU FAMILIA CON SU TRABAJO.
texts.en:
The partners who make up the Group "Paraiso Norte” are people who have known each other for some time as they reside in the same area. They are represented by Señora Estela, who is the president of the group. The majority of members run small business that sell products such as clothing, cosmetics, food, beverages, and service activities such as construction, coking, and electronic repairs. Within the scope of services, there is strong competition for supply and demand, but the members’ experience and their years of service make it more bearable. They are requesting funding for the purchase of materials and tools to offer an improved product and service to meet market demand. Members are capable of managing the requested funds because they have experience with group credit and understand how to respond and comply with their responsibilities, as they are people wanting to improve the quality of life for their family through their work.

Translated from Spanish by Carrie Ting, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For capital

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame  Kadia D.  a 36 ans, elle réside avec son époux et leurs 5 enfants (1 garçon et 4 filles) à Mamassoni, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Kadia D. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à la fabrique des savons traditionnels (savons noirs) il y a maintenant six (06) ans qu’elle a appris auprès d’une amie. Elle mène son activité dans son domicile de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée par une grande clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois (03) ans. Après 2 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) avec une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 4 futs des déchets d’huile de coton (pates noires) et 2 sacs de soude caustique. Après fabrication des savons à base de déchets d’huile de coton et de soude caustique, elle les revend en détail de façon ambulante à une clientèe composée généralement des femmes de sa localité..
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadia D., 36, resides with her husband and their 5 children (one son and 4 daughters) in Mamassoni, an outlying district of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mrs. Kadia D., after having tried out a lot of businesses without success, began to manufacture traditional soap (black soap) 6 years ago, when she learned the skill from a friend. She runs this business out of her home in Sikasso where she is much in demand with a big clientele due to the quality of her product. To satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided 3 years ago to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After two group loans together with an association of women from her neighborhood, she is now on her third individual loan, all preceding loans having been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan she intends to buy 4 barrels of cotton oil waste (a black paste) and two sacks of caustic soda. After making the soap out of this cotton oil waste and caustic soda, she sells it retail door-to-door to a clientele mainly made up of women from her neighborhood.

With this loan she expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA which will be used essentially to grow her working capital and cover her costs, contributing to family expenses and making repayments on her loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing cotton oil waste (black paste) and caustic soda to make soap

loans.name: Llegando Lejos Iii Group

texts.en: Eugenia M. J. is bank coordinator for a group called Llegando Lejos (Going Far). Her group has five members. She is 35 years old. She lives with her spouse and five children; ages 16, 11, 8, 7 and 2 years old. She sells chicken in her own community in El Seybo. She has already received three loans from Esperanza and is about to receive her fourth. She would like to increase her business by selling a greater quantity of products, such as sugar and coffee; and to expand her activities by selling deodorant. She finds keeping the clients happy to be the biggest challenge in her daily activities. She would also like to improve her house and make her business grow to provide for her large family. On behalf of Esperanza and the Llegando Lejos Bank of Hope, thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase new consumer goods and expand business with new personal care products.

loans.name: Harriet No Oyoo

texts.fr: O. harriet est une esthéticienne dans le quartier de nykonakpoè, elle a beaucoup de clientèle, elle a associé à son activité la vente de produits de beauté, elle  fait cette activité depuis 2003. Elle est donc très sollicitée dans son quartier et a besoin d’agrandir son commerce c’est pour cela qu’elle demande à WAGES un crédit d’un montant de 500000F pour acheter des marchandises de produits de beauté. Elle est mariée et a 01 enfants, son mari est un  gestionnaire  à la SVT.
texts.en:
Harriet O. is a beautician in the Nykonakpoè neighborhood. She has a lot of customers and she sells cosmetics as well. She has been in this business since 2003. She is very much in demand in her neighborhood and thus needs to expand her business. For that reason, she is asking for a loan from WAGES in the amount of 500,000 F to buy cosmetics. She is married with one child, and her husband is a manager at the SVT.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Reyna Sulema

texts.es: La Sra.: Reyna tiene 53 años de edad, ha sido una mujer luchadora desde su juventud, procreo 4 hijos todos ellos trabajan y están independiente pero que los apoyan, su esposo se desempeña en servicios de vigilancias,  reside en  Hialeah IV etapa, ella vende hielos y helados  que inicio para ayudar  a su esposo con los gastos.con esta solicitud va invertir terminar de construir las paredes de su casa para lograr mejor seguridad con su familia, para esto necesita comprar materiales de construcción: como piedra, arena, hierro y otros. Con este préstamo doña Reyna se siente beneficiada ya que gracias a estos préstamos va a poder lograr sus sueños. Entre sus planes es poder ofertar otros productos que le generen ingresos como la captación de clientes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Reyna is 53 years old and has been a motivated woman since her youth. She has 4 children all of whom work and are independent but she and her husband support them. Her husband works in security. She resides in the Hialeah IV area.

Mrs. Reyna sells ice and ice creams, a business that she began in order to help her husband with their living expenses. With her solicited loan she will invest in finishing the construction of the walls of her home in order to provide more security for her family. For this she needs to buy construction materials such as: stone, sand, iron and other materials. Mrs. Reyna feels blessed to have this loan and thanks to the loan she will be able to achieve her dreams. In addition to finishing the walls in her home she also plans to offer other products in her business that will generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Breanne Kochert, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build concrete walls in her house

loans.name: Las Tiluchis Group

texts.es: LOS SOCIOS (AS) QUIENES CONFORMAN EL GRUPO "LAS TILUCHIS" SON PERSONAS RESPONSABLES Y MUY EMPRENDEDORAS COMO LO DEMOSTRARON EN UN ANTERIOR FINANCIAMIENTO CON LA FUNDACIÓN AGROCAPITAL YA QUE CURSAN SU SEGUNDO CICLO CON RESPONSABILIDAD Y HONESTIDAD, ESTÁN REPRESENTADAS POR LA SEÑORA BEATRIZ QUIEN ES LA PRESIDENTA DEL GRUPO. EN GENERAL LAS SOCIAS SE DEDICAN AL COMERCIO D. DIFERENTES PRODUCTOS COMO COSMÉTICOS, CAJAS, COMIDA Y A LA PRESTACIÓN D. SERVICIOS COMO ESTILISTAS, CONTADORES, CARPINTERÍA Y ALA ELABORACIÓN D. PAN. DENTRO DEL ÁMBITO LABORAL EXISTE MUCHA COMPETENCIA PERO DEPEND. D. CADA UNA EL MEJORAR SU PRODUCTO A LA VENTA CON MEJORES MATERIALES E INSUMOS Y A MEJORAR SUS HERRAMIENTAS D. TRABAJO PARA BRINDAR UN MEJOR SERVICIO, ES PARA ESTO QUE REQUIEREN D. FINANCIAMIENTO PARA LA ADQUISICIÓN D. INSUMOS MATERIALES Y HERRAMIENTAS D. TRABAJO PARA INCREMENTAR SUS INGRESOS Y MEJORAR SU CALIDAD D. VIDA Y LA D. SUS FAMILIAS.
texts.en:
The members who form the "Las Tiluchis" group are responsible and very enterprising people which they demonstrated in a previous financing with the Agrocapital Foundation now that they are in their second funding with responsibility and honesty, they are represented by Beatriz, who is the president of the group. In general the member are dedicated to selling different products like cosmetics, boxes, food and the presentation of services like stylists, contractors, carpenters, and to making bread. Within the work environment there is a lot of competence, but each depends on improving her products with better materials and products and improving her tools to achieve a better service, which is why they require financing for the acquisition of materials and tools to increase their earnings and improve their standards of living, along with their families'.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadia S. a 36 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 4 enfants (01 garçon et 3 filles) à Kaboila I Natien, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Kadia S. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,  s’est initié à cette activité de restauration il y a maintenant quinze (15) ans. Elle mène son activité devant le domicile conjugal en face de la Direction Régionale des Affaires Sociales tous les jours où elle est beaucoup sollicitée  par une grande clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits.
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de quatre (4) ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 7ème prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce septième prêt: 50kg de poissons frais, 60 sachets d’Attièkè, 100kg de pomme de terre, 20kg de viande de boeuf, des bananes plantains (Aloko), etc. Elle achète ses marchandises sur place.
Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée très généralement des jeunes (célibataires) surtout de main d’oeuvre puisque sa place n’est pas loin du marché. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour  ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs Kadia S. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and 4 children (one boy and three girls) in Kaboila Natien, located at the center of Sikasso (third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). Mrs.S. after several unsuccessful attempts, started a restaurant business fifteen years ago. She operates her business daily across from the Direction of Regional Social Affair building where she was able to build a large clientele who enjoy her quality produits. To satisfy the needs of an increasing number of clients, she decided, four years ago, to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance association. After several group loans with an assiciation of women from her neighborhood, she is now on her seventh individual loan. All these loans were duly repaid.
