Mrs. S. M. is a small producer of rice. Her husband suffers from mobility problems, and she is requesting this loan because she must see to both the rice production and the home. All her children are now grown and living on their own. She tends to her areas of production on a daily basis; with the current loan, she would like to become part of a group of owners of a rice thresher. This would allow her to generate better income from her production.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To contribute toward construction of a rice thresher.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. is thirty-four years old. She is divorced but has given birth to three children -- two boys and a girl. Abena says two of her children are currently in primary school, while the last is yet to start. She lives with her family in a rented house in Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Offinso is both a farming and commercial community.

Abena works very hard to take care of the children as her ex-husband does not contribute in any way as far as the children’s upkeep is concerned. She sells fresh yam in the local market square. She procures the tubers of yam from the farmers in her community and those in the surrounding villages. Abena has been in business for eight years. She also distributes the yam to some food vendors in her community. She wants a loan to buy tubers of yam on a large scale so that she can distribute to more customers, and probably trek to nearby towns to sell, so she can increase her profit margin. It is her dream to give all her children good formal education.

loans.use: To buy yams in bulk and increase her business

loans.name: Marcos Antonio

texts.es: Don Marcos es un pequeño productor agricola que habita en la finca junto a su familia compuesta por 5 hijos y su esposa, 3 de sus hijos estudian y trabajan junto a su papá en tiempo libre, la esposa todos los dias garantiza la alimentacion de sus hijos y su marido, a la vez cria especies menores (gallina y cerdos) para aportar al sostenimiento del hogar.  El mayor sueño de don Marcos es asociarse en la construccion del trillo arrocero, para lo que solicita el credito.
texts.en:
Don Marcos is a small agricultural producer who lives on a farm with his family, which is comprised of five children and his wife. Three of his children study and work along with their father in their free time. His wife guarantees that her husband and kids are fed every day. She also raises small animals (chickens and pigs) to support their family. Don Marcos' biggest dream is to be associated with the construction of a rice thresher, which is why he's requesting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in the construction of a rice thresher

loans.name: Lissett Benita

texts.es:
La Joven de Nombre Lisset Benita Z. Z. tiene la edad de 28 años, su estado civil es soltera, La Joven Lisset no tiene hijos sus propósitos son de seguir trabajando ya que tiene mucha vida por delante y le gustaría generar mas ingresos para su familia ya que su Mama y sus hermanas están a su cargo  por lo que es ella quien es la encargada de la manutención de su familia sus deseos son de terminar sus estudios ya que sigue estudiando y trabajando por lo que no quiere dejar de estudiar ya que sus padres no le ofrecieron este tipo de oportunidad y ahora con sus propios esfuerzos lo esta logrando sus sueños son de ofrecer en un futuro a sus hijos la oportunidad de estudiar para que ellos puedan tener esta posibilidad es por eso que tiene que ahorra en un futuro además de establecerse de forma mas segura en su negocio para que este le siga propiciando los beneficios que ha obtenido hasta los momentos.


La actividad económica a la que Doña Lissett se dedica es una pulpería de ropa y cosméticos, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 6 años, Doña Lissett inicia este negocio por su familia ya que desde hace mucho tiempo este era el medio de trabajo pero debido a las circunstancias económicas tuvieron que renunciar este tipo de negocio y es así que nace la inspiración del la fuente de ingresos para su familia y decide reestablecer el negocio familiar por cuenta propia y decide comenzar con pocos productos como: ropa interior y dulces y lo hacia de forma ambulante en La Terminal por lo que sus deseos de superación eran mas fuertes por lo que no podía dejar este medio de trabajo ya que tenia que pagar las deudas contraídas y poco a poco fue adquiriendo el capital necesario para progresar con su negocio y no le fue nada fácil por que ella misma tenia que realizar la venta de los productos y a la misma ves encargarse de las compras y solo tiempo le ayudo a adaptarse para sobrevivir con este tipo de trabajo por lo que ahora solicita el financiamiento destinado para capital de trabajo ya que necesita realizar las compras de sus productos como: cosméticos, ropa y productos escolares ya que se acerca la temporada de la entrada a clases y además tiene que viajar a Managua y Chinandega por lo que en estos lugares compra de forma mas favorable.
texts.en:
Lisset Benita Z. Z. is 28 years old, single and has no children. Her intention is to keep working since she has a long time to make headway and she would like to generate more income for her family. She provides for her mother and sisters. Her wish is to finish her studies because it is an opportunity her parents never had, and thanks to her efforts she is fulfilling her dreams of being able to offer the same opportunity to her future children. It's for this reason she must save for the future as well as establish a more stable business.

Lissett makes a living selling clothing and cosmetics at an outdoor sales post, which she has been doing for six years. She started the business for her family because for a long time this had been their means of income but due to economic circumstances they were forced to give up the business. From this came the inspiration to decide to re-establish the family business on her own and regain their source of income. She chose to start out with just a few products, such as underwear and candy, and sold the products in The Terminal outdoor market. Her desires to make headway were ever stronger because she also had to repay the debts she took on to start it. Little by little she acquired the capital necessary to make progress with her business, and nothing came easy because she not only had to make the sales but also make the purchases. Only time helped her adapt to surviving in this line of work, to which she is now requesting a loan to purchase products such as cosmetics, clothing and school supplies since school season is nearing. She also needs to travel to Managua and Chinandega because those are the best areas to make these purchases.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products such as cosmetics, clothing and school supplies

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roman Alberto

texts.es: Roman es un pequeño productor arrocero reconocido en su comunidad por su dedicacion a la siembra de este cultivo, habita en la finca junto a su familia compuesta por sus dos hijos de 6 y 10 años que estudian la primaria en la escuela de la comunidad. La esposa ademas de atender el hogar tambien da clase como docente de primaria.  Don Roman con este credito tiene la intencion de participar como socio de la construccion de un trillo arrocero y asi alcanzar su sueño como productor de cultivo de arroz.
texts.en:
Roman is a small-scale rice grower who is well-known in his community because of his dedication to this crop. He lives on the farm with his family, which is comprised of two children, ages 6 and 10, who attend the local elementary school. Aside from her household duties, his wife also works as an elementary school teacher. Mr. Roman will use this loan to participate as a member in the construction of a rice threshing machine, thus he can reach his dream as a rice grower.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Contribution towards building a rice threshing machine

loans.name: María

texts.es:
La Sra. Maria G. esta casada con el Sr. Clotilde hace 40 años, el matrimonio posee 2 hijos mayores de edad ya casados.

Ella es docente jubilada y posee su negocio de venta de artesanías hace 4 años.

 Se dedica a la venta de productos artesanales como ser: hamacas, jarrones, macetas, floreros de barro y varias otras  producciones artesanales tradicionales.

Comenta que en el negocio la venta es muy buena y que necesita de un préstamo para compra de mayor número de mercaderías debido a la demanda que tiene de las mismas.
texts.en:
Maria G. has been married to her husband Clotilde for 40 years and they have two children who are grown up and married. She is a retired teacher and has had her business selling crafts for four years. She makes a living selling artisan work such as hammocks, vases, flowerpots, clay pots and other traditional crafts. She says that her sales are very good and she needs a loan to purchase a larger supply of merchandise due to the demand it is receiving.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase craftwork

loans.name: Angelina

texts.es:
Angélina es socia del Bancomunal  Los Cipreses. 
Angélina es casada, tiene 43 años, dos hijos de 16 y 10 años estudian en el colegio estatal Juan Vales.
Angélina es la menor de doce hermanos, ella era una niña cuando su papá falleció, gracias a Dios y al esfuerzo de su familia  llegó a estudiar costura y  trabajó  cosiendo con una amiga en su casa. Por las noches vendía anticuchos en la puerta de su casa, cuando se casó su esposo no quiso que siguiera trabajando: Pero después de unos años  la necesidad le hizo que  volviera a trabajar, entonces decidió vender ropa.  
Angélina agradece a Finca porque le ayudó con los préstamos en tiempos difíciles, le gusta las reuniones porque recibe consejos de la promotora, quien les dice: no se metan en cuentas que no pueden pagar.

Angélina necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para comprar mercadería de ropa que los clientes le piden.
Angélina tiene una meta  para este año que es comprar un carro sandwichero, y para un futuro hacer una boutique en su casa y ver a sus hijos profesionales.
texts.en:
Angelina is a member of the The Cypresses (Los Cipreses) Village Bank. She is 43 years old, married, with 2 children (16 years old and 10 years old) who are students in the Juan Vales state school. Angelina is the youngest of 12 children and was a child when her father passed away. Thanks to God and her family's efforts, she was able to study to be a seamstress and she worked sewing with a friend in her home. At night she would sell cow-heart kebabs (a popular Peruvian food) from the door of her home. When she got married, her husband didn't want her to continue working. However, after a few years, it became necessary for her to go back to work so she decided to sell clothes. Angelina is grateful to Finca because it has helped her with loans during difficult times. She likes the meetings she attends for Finca because she receives good counsel from the promoter, such as: don't get involved in debts you can't repay. Angelina needs a loan of $325 to purchase clothing that her customers are asking for. She has the goal this year of purchasing a sandwich cart, to put a boutique in her home in the future, and to eventually see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing that her customers order

loans.name: Dina

texts.es:
Dina es social del Bancomunal Los Cipreses. 
Dina es Ayacuchana, conviviente, tiene 38 años, tiene dos hijos de 15 y 18 años, ellos estudian en la escuela y trabajan. 
En Ayacucho vendía comida  en el mercado, perteneció a un Bancomunal; Cuando llegó a Lima se integró a un Bancomunal cerca de su casa, se puso a vender caldo de gallina  “Gálvez” en Villa el Salvador, en el mercado es conocida como la cancherita. Desde hace tres años; cada día, vende 200 platos de caldo de gallina, lamentablemente en diciembre sufrió un robo, se quedó dormida en su puesto, se llevaron sus servicios y su olla con caldo de gallina.  
Empezó  su negocio cuando ingresó a Finca, le han orientado en cómo trabajar, cómo atender a su familia, aprendió a ser reciproca con las personas. 
Dina necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles para comprar fideos, huevos, aceite, al por mayor también va comprar platos y cucharas.
El sueño de Dina es construir su casa, esta comprando un terreno en partes y que sus hijos  terminen de estudiar.
texts.en:
Dina is a member of The Cypresses (Los Cipreses) Village Bank. She is from the province of Ayacucho and lives with her partner; she is 38 years old with two children (15 and 18 years old) who both study and work. In Ayacucho, she used to sell food in the market and she belonged to a village bank there; when she arrived in Lima, she became involved in a village bank close to her home and she began her business "G. Chicken Soup" in Villa el Salvador. In the market where she sells, she is known as "the experience woman." For the past three years, she has sold 200 bowls of chicken soup per day, but sadly, in December, she was robbed. She was sleeping in her stand and the robbers took much of her table and dishware and her large pot. She started her business when she became involved with Finca and they have taught her how to work, how to take care of her family, and she learned to give back to those around her. She needs a $950 loan to purchase noodles, eggs, and oil wholesale and she will also purchase plates and spoons. Dina's dream is to build her house and she plans to purchase land to do so; she also wants her children to finish studying.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase noodles, eggs, and oil wholesale; also purchase plates and spoons

loans.name: Rokiatou

texts.fr:
Mademoiselle Rokiatou C. est une célibataire de 28 ans et mère d’1enfant. Elle vit chez son feu père  dans le quartier Niébala de Bougouni.(troisième région adminitrative de la république de Mali). 
Suite au décès de son, Mademoiselle Rokiatou C. décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus notamment afin d’aider sa mère à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille. Elle avait tenté pendant des années différentes activités sans succès en raison surtout de la faiblesse de son fonds de commerce. Elle finit par opter pour l’achat et la vente des habits, chaussures, parfums...  qu’elle a appris auprès d’une soeur. Avec une expérience de 4 ans elle maîtrise bien son activité et est très sollicitée.
Pour obtenir un fonds de commerce substantiel Rokiatou C. décida d’intégrer une association de son quartier. Après 9 prêts en solidaire (prêt de groupe), elle est passée au prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Avec ce premier  prêt individuel  elle compte acheter, 3 cartons de parfums, 20 draps, 30 paires de chaussures 10 piéces de tissus et 5 jeux complets de tasses. Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Fasso et à Bamako. La vente se fait au marché mais aussi dans le quartier. La plus part de sa sa clientèle est composée essentiellement des femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA Avec se bénéfice elle compte payer les intérêts du prêts et agrandir son entreprise..
texts.en:
Ms. Rokiatou C., age 28, is single and the mother of one child. She lives in the home of her deceased father in the Niébala neighborhood in Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Following her father's death, Ms. Rokiatou C. decided to start money-making businesses, notably to help her mother provide for the family expenses. For years, she had tried various businesses, all unsuccessful, mostly due to her low working capital. She finally chose to buy and sell clothes, shoes, perfumes, ... a business she learned from one sister. With four years of experience, she is now very good at her business, and she is in high demand. In order to obtain a substantial working capital, Rokiatou C. decided to join a neighborhood group. After 9 solidarity loans (group loans) that were all repaid without problem, she's now seeking her first individual loan. With this loan, she intends to buy 3 boxes of perfumes, 20 sheets, 30 pairs of shoes, 10 pieces of fabric, and 5 sets of cups. She gets her supplies in Burkina Fasso and in Bamako. She sells at the market, but also in her neighborhood. Her clientele comprises mostly women. She foresees a monthly profit of XOF 35'000 (ca US$ 70), to be used to repay the loan and to expand her business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de draps, chaussures, tissus, tasses et parfums.To buy and resell sheets, shoes, fabrics, and perfumes

loans.name: Nuevo Renacer 3 & 4 Group

texts.en: Juana R. is a member of the Nuevo Renacer Bank of Hope in Sabana Perdida, a neighborhood located in the northern outskirts of Santo Domingo. This area also happens to be very close to the Ozama River, so this is a threatened area during rainy season due to the river`s overflowing. This loan is for groups 3 and 4 of this bank. For group 3 it`s their second loan and for group 4 it's their first loan.  Juana owns a colmado, which is a small convenience store where you can buy groceries for your daily cooking, among other supplies. Most of her clients live in her neighborhood. She would like to increase her business even more and hopes that one day she will also be able to employ one person that can help her with her business. Juana dreams of owning a larger store where she can sell better, more varied products, and hopefully allow her to improve her house condition. On behalf of Esperanza and the Nuevo Renacer Bank of Hope, thank you for your support!

loans.use: purchase merchandise to restock colmado

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Francisca es socia del Bancomunal Los Cipreses.
Francisca, es de Apurimac tiene 56 años, cuatro hijos de 24, 22, 20,  y 14 años, los mayores estudian y trabajan  el último esta en la escuela.
Francisca solo estudió la primaria por motivos económicos, pero ha podido surgir en la vida, sabe leer solo números, no sabe escribir correctamente. 
Ella es separada pero recibe ayuda económica de su esposo. Se dedica a la venta de ropa, vende en su casa y también deja a domicilio, también vende productos de belleza por catalogo. Hace poco por intermedio de una amiga se contactó para que tejiera aretes para exportación, para ella es una entrada mas  y se siente contenta.  
Desde que está en Finca ha recibido apoyo de los préstamos, que le han ayudado a  que su capital crezca, aprendió a invertir, recibe orientación de su promotora cada vez que se reúne en el Bancomunal, 
Francisca necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para comprar mercadería  de ropa, también para cubrir  la venta de productos de belleza  por catalogo.
El sueño de Francisca que quiere ver realizado es poner su tienda  de abarrotes en su casa.
texts.en:
Francisca is a member of The Cypresses (Los Cipreses) Village Bank. She is from Apurimac and is 56 years old. She has four children (24, 22, 20, and 14 years old); the oldest children study and work and the youngest child is still in high school. Francisca only was able to study through elementary school due to the financial situation of her family, but she has been able to progress in life nonetheless; she knows numbers and basic math but does not know how to read or write correctly. She is separated from her husband, but she still receives some child support from him. She sells clothing from her home and delivers it to her customers; she also sells beauty products from catalogues. A short time ago, a friend contacted her about an opportunity exporting weaved earrings; for Francisca it is another source of income and she feels very content with it. Since she became involved in Finca, she has received support through loans that have helped her capital to grow; she also learned how to invest as she has received training from her promoter each time that she meets with the Village Bank. Francisca needs a $325 loan to purchase clothing and to cover the sales cost of the beauty products. Francisca's dream is to eventually put up a small general/grocery store in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing and cover selling costs of catalogue beauty products

loans.name: Assitan

texts.fr:
Madame Assitan Konaté est une femme divorcée de 40 ans et mère de trois (3) enfants. Enseignante à l’école de Sanankoroba(deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali)  à 35   kilomètres de Bamako (la capitale du Mali) elle vit dans la cité des enseignants. 
En plus de ses obligations professionnelles, elle fait le commerce de charbon de bois, du bois de chauffe, du beurre de karité et du miel destiné aux marchés de la capitale Bamako. 
Dans le souci d’améliorer ses affaires, elle intégra le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y‘a deux ans. Elle est à son troisième prêt individuel, et tous les deux prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle veut acheter  40  kilogrammes de beurre de karité, 75  litres de miel et 3 tonnes de charbon de bois et du bois de chauffe. Elle fait ses achats deux par semaines avant d’aller les revendre à Bamako par l’entremise de sa mère et sa fille. Elle vend ses produits aux revendeurs des marchés généralement en gros, au comptant  et à  crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de  50.000FCFA destinés à rembourser les intérêts du prêt et  satisfaire aux besoins de sa famille.
Madame Assitan Konaté ambitionne augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en vu de ravitailler  les marchés des zones désertiques en  miel et en beurre de karité.
texts.en:
Ms. Assitan Konaté is a divorcée, 40 years of age, the mother of three, and a teacher at the school of Sanankoroba (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali) located 35 km from Bamako, the capital of Mali. She lives in the teachers' section of town. In addition to her professional obligations, she does commerce in charcoal, firewood, karité butter (made from the shea nut), and honey for the marketplaces of Bamako.

Concerned about improving her business, she joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago and is on her third individual loan. Both preceding ones have been repaid. With this new loan, she wants to buy 40 kg of karité butter, 75 liters of honey, 3 tonnes of charcoal and of firewood. She does her buying twice a week and then goes to resell the goods in Bamako through her mother and daughter. She sells goods to marketplace retailers generally wholesale, cash or credit accepted.

She intends to realize a monthly profit of 50,000 francs for repaying the loan interest and to meet the needs of the family. She has the ambition to increase her sales figures with the goal of resupplying the desert-area marketplaces with honey and karité butter.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal, firewood, karité butter, and honey

loans.name: Lidia Del Transito

texts.es:
La Señora Lidia del Transito R. López tiene la edad de 54 años, su estado civil es soltera, Doña Lidia tiene 2 hijas ambas están casadas y mayores de edad, sus propósitos son proporcionarle las mejoras necesarias a su vivienda para que en un futuro sus hijos gocen de su vivienda sus deseos son de establecer una pulpería con todas las condiciones necesarias para dedicarse completamente a este negocio y obtener su jubilación ya que necesita ingresos para la compra de sus medicamentos por lo que Doña Lidia ha buscado el medio para trabajar y es por medio de la venta de frijoles, leña refrescos entre otros ya que siempre le ha gustado trabajar y es lo que le enseña a sus hijos para que ellos aprendan lo difícil que es trabajar y ganar dinero sus sueños son que Dios le de mas vida para enseñarles a su hijos a trabajar fuertemente y como administrar un negocio ya que es importante por lo que así obtendrán una fuente de ingresos.


La actividad económica es la venta de ropa interior, venta de refrescos, venta de frijoles cocidos y la venta de leña, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación ubicada en el costado norte del restaurante Dilectus, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 12 años, su actividad económica inicia por los deseos de superación y con la necesidad de buscar una fuente de ingresos que sufragara los gastos propios del hogar y el sustento diario de sus 2 hijas, es así que a pesar de contar con una plaza fija de docente de educación primaria surge la idea através de sus hijas de vender refrescos, gaseosa, leña y todo esto ubicado en su casa de habitación siendo atendido por sus hijas ya que cuando Doña Lidia tenia que impartir clases por las mañanas ella cuidaban del negocio por lo que en las tardes ella se hacia cargo del negocio al pasar el tiempo decide abrir ofertas de sus productos en su centro de trabajo y empieza ofertando ropa interior de contado y al crédito a sus colegas y padres de familia de sus estudiantes teniendo hasta la fecha la clientela por lo que el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo destinado para la compra de mas productos de belleza y productos de pulpería para aprovechar la temporada ya que la clientela le solicita constantemente nuevos productos.
texts.en:
Lidia del Transito R. López is 54 years old, single and has two daughters, both of whom are grown up and married. Her goal is to make the necessary improvements to her home so her children can enjoy it in the future. Her wish is to establish a convenience store with all the necessary elements and dedicate herself completely to the business and receive a pension, since she needs the income to pay for her medications. Lidia has looked for a way to work, and in doing this started selling beans, firewood and beverages, among other items, and always has enjoyed it. She taught her children the trade so they'd learn the difficulty of hard work and making money. Her dream is for God to grant her a long life so she can teach her children to work hard and how to administer her business, since it is important for them to have a source of income.

Lidia's main economic activity is selling undergarments, beverages, cooked beans and firewood. Her business is located in her home on the side of Dilectus restaurant. She has had her business for 12 years, which started out of her desire to make headway and out of the necessity to find a source of income to cover household expenses and provide for her two daughters. With a fixed primary educational plan, the idea came to her she could teach her children and also tend to her business. That way when she gave them lessons in the mornings she could take care of the business as well, and in the afternoons could focus fully on her work. As time passed she decided to start offering undergarments by order and on credit. She is requesting a loan to purchase beauty products and other convenience store products to take advantage of the season and because her clientele is constantly requesting new products.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products and other convenience store supplies

loans.name: Rosa Martbel

texts.es:
Rosa es socia del Bancomunal Los Cipreses. 
Rosa es conviviente, tiene 28 años dos hijos de 4 y 6 años, quienes están en la escuela.
Rosa llegó hace dos años del norte del Perú, Piura con su esposo y dos  hijos; aquí en Lima tiene familia que la animó a entrar en el negocio de compra y venta de antigüedades. Consiguiendo un capital decidieron entrar al negocio, ahora trabaja junto con su esposo, su puesto queda en un campo ferial se llama “501”, le gusta su negocio porque las personas le cuentan cómo adquirieron sus muebles. Conoce muchas cosas, el mueble mas antiguo que ella pudo comprar para después venderlo fue de los años 40 que llegó un poco deteriorado, pero su esposo se dedica a resanar cuando llegan muebles magullados.
Desde que esta en Finca tienen para invertir y valerse por si solos, ellos viven en casa alquilada, aprendió en el Bancomunal cómo administrar su negocio.
Rosa necesita un crédito de 1200 soles, para la compra de muebles antiguos.
Rosa y su esposo tiene una meta que es tener un local mas para seguir vendiendo antigüedades, y le gustaría estudiar cosmetología.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of The Cypresses (Los Cipreses) Village Bank. She lives with her husband and is 28 years old; she has two children (4 and 6 years old) who are in elementary school. Rosa came from Piura in the north of Peru with her husband and two children; here in Lima she has family that encouraged her to start a business selling antiques. She was able to obtain enough capital to start the business which she now runs with her husband. Her antique stand is in a fairground called "501;" she likes her business especially for the stories the people tell her of how they obtained their antique furniture. The oldest piece of furniture she purchased was from the 1940s and arrived somewhat deteriorated, but her husband is able to fix furniture that arrives in bad shape. Since she became involved in Finca, they have been able to invest in their business and take care of themselves; they live in a rented home. She has learned how to better manage her business through the Village Bank. Rosa needs a $400 loan to purchase more antique furniture. Rosa and her husband have the goal of expanding to a larger locale to sell more antiques, and someday she would like to study cosmetology.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase antique furniture

loans.name: Carlos Enoc

texts.es:
El Joven Carlos Enoc Z. F. tiene la edad de 23 años, su estado civil es soltero, Carlos no tiene hijos, su propósitos son seguir innovando en su negocio para que este crezca de manera gradual ya que todavía no tiene una familia a quien brindarle las comodidades necesarias solamente su Mama y sus hermanas, sus sueños como todo joven emprendedor son de ayudar establecer una tienda de mercadería en general y le gustaría que la administración este a cargo de su Mama ya que hasta los momentos el es quien se encarga de mantenerla y con este negocio obtendría mas ingresos y además no le seria difícil captar la atención de sus clientes ya que con el negocio que tiene le seria mucho mas fácil sus deseos son de algún día obtener su vivienda propia ya que le gustaría independizarse de su Mama por lo que todavía habita en la casa de habitación de ella y le gustaría acondicionarla con las comodidades necearías y así también le daría un buen hogar a la que será su futura familia. 

Su actividad económica es la venta de tortillas, ropa y cosméticos, la ubicación de su negocio es en Malpaisillo en su casa de habitación, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 14 años, el Joven Carlos inicia este negocio porque tenia que responder por la responsabilidades de su hogar además tenia que mantener a su Mama y sus hermanas por lo que decide iniciar con al venta de tortillas y las ofrecía de forma ambulante por todo las calles de Malpaisillo y así fue logrando obtener a sus clientes por demostrar dinamismo al ofrecer sus productos pero esto era muy poco para satisfacer el sustento de su familia por lo que decide dedicarse también a la venta de de ropa como: trajes para niños, faldas, camisas y pantalones y después de terminar con el recorrido de la venta de tortillas continuaba con el recorrido de la venta de ropa y esto lo logro por que algunos clientes le compraban las tortillas y así mismo aprovecho la oportunidad para ofertar la ropa a estos mismo clientes por lo que ambos negocio le gustaron ahora necesita un financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la inversión de sus productos ya que se acerca la temporada de la entrada a clases y le gustaría suplirse con algunos productos y agradece personalmente a las organizaciones amigas y a la Fundación León 2000 por realizar todas las obras a favor de las personas que les gusta el trabajo digno y humilde.
texts.en:
Carlos Enoc Z. F. is 23 years old, and single. Carlos doesn't have children, and he'd like to continue innovating his business. Carlos sells tortillas, clothes, and cosmetics. His business is located in his home in Malpaisillo, and he's had the store for 14 years. Carlos opened the store because he had a responsibility to his home and had to support his mother and sisters. He therefore began to make tortillas, and sell them on the streets of Malpaisillo. He began to earn customers by demonstrating his dynamism when selling his products. Even so, his earnings were not enough to sustain his family so he began to sell clothing, such as: childrens' suits, skirts, shirts, and pants. After doing his rounds selling tortillas, Carlos would continue on to sell clothing. This was a success because some clients who bought tortillas also took the opportunity to buy clothing. His business is growing slowly because he still doesn't have a family of his own to support, only his mother and his sisters. This hard-working, young entrepreneur dreams of helping establish a general store and he'd like his mother to manage the finances. Carlos is responsible for supporting her and with this business he'd earn enough to do so. Carlos wouldn't find it difficult to capture the attention of his customers with a general store, because it would be much easier than with his current business. Carlos would one day like to own his home, as he currently lives with his mother but would like to become more independent. He'd also like to give his mother the basic commodities and a nice home where his future family will live. Now Carlos needs working capital to invest in his products, because the school year is beginning and he'd like to stock his store. Carlos personally thanks Fundación León 2000 and its partner organizations of for all of their work in support of people who enjoy dignified and humble work.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr:
Madame Bintou  S. est une femme mariée de trente quatre (34) ans, mère de deux (2) enfants qui vit dans une famille polygame dans la sous- préfecture de Selingué.
Dès le bas âge elle apprit la production de la pâte d’arachide auprès de sa mère très réputée et expérimentée en la matière.  
Afin d’améliorer ses activités, elle intégra le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso maintenant deux ans. Après trois prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous bien remboursés ; elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel avec lequel elle compte acheter,  600  kilogrammes d’arachide et 25 bassinets en plastique pour emballage.
Elle s’approvisionne une fois par mois auprès des producteurs des villages environnants de Sélingué. Les grains d’arachide une fois bien triés, sont asséchés, grillés et vannés. Après ils sont  amenés au moulin pour obtenir de la pâte (condiment très prisé dans la ration alimentaire malienne)  et emballée dans des bassinets pour être vendue sur le marché en gros. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 55.000  F CFA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer l’échéance du  prêt.
texts.en:
Ms. Bintou S. is a married woman, 34 years of age, and the mother two. She lives in a polygamous family in the sub-prefecture of Selingué. Since she was very young, she learned how to make peanut butter from her mother, who is highly regarded and experienced in it.

In order to improve her business, she joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago. After three solidarity loans (group loans), all repaid, she is on her second individual loan, which she plans to use for buying: 600 kg of peanuts and 25 plastic tubs for packaging. She gets supplies once a month from farmers in the surrounding villages of Sélingué. Once the peanuts are sorted, they are dried, roasted, and winnowed. Then they are taken to the mill for making the peanut butter (a very popular condiment among the staple foods of Mali) and for packing it into tubs to be sold wholesale.

She hopes to realize an average monthly profit of 55,000 francs CFA that will be used to help cover family expenses and to make loan payments.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of peanuts to make peanut butter

loans.name: Abiba

texts.en:
Abiba S. is a 29-year-old woman. She is married but has no children. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home, in a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Abiba is an achiever and a resourceful woman. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living.

Abiba has been trading bananas in Abofour market for four years. She treks to surrounding villages in the Central part of Ghana to purchase bulk stock of bananas from farmers and to retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick up enough stock to make enough profit to support her family. Abiba will buy the unripe banana in bulk, and she will cover it with plantain leaves in the bush. This would be there for a while so when it is ripe she would go for them and retail to her customers.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk supply of bananas to enable the scale-up of her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her business growth. Abiba belongs to a village bank (loan group) called ‘Paul.’ She also hopes to receive GH¢600 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to support her husband in taking care of their home.

loans.use: To purchase a supply of bananas in bulk.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda S. is her name, and she is a 42-year-old woman, married, and mother of six kids. Four of the children are currently in school in the community where they live, while two are independent.

Linda has been a food vendor for three years, selling kenkey. Through this she has sent her kids to school. She prepares and sells kenkey in Abofour, a farming community where she lives with her household. Aside from this business, she also sells raw food products like maize in the market place of Abofour, mostly during their market days on Thursdays. The food she prepares is a delicious dish that many Ghanaians enjoy everyday either as breakfast, lunch or dinner, especially where she lives. Her business is doing well, and she wants to expand her operations to serve more customers. With the loan, she wants to buy more maize grains, firewood, sugar etc. for her operation. She also wants to use part of the money to provide education for her kids. She hopes this loan will help her increase her savings to improve her family's wellbeing. She would be very grateful for that assistance. Linda belongs to a village bank (loan group) called ‘Sarah’. She also hopes to receive GH¢400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to support her husband in taking care of their home.

loans.use: To buy bags of dried maize grains, rice, vegetables, assorted meat, etc.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort W. is 48 years old. She is married and the mother of six kids. Two have completed junior high school; but for lack of funds they could continue their education to the senior high school level. Comfort lives with her family and husband in a house in Abofour in the Ashanti region. Through the government basic compulsory education her little kids are now in school.

She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes her livelihood. She sells in a community called Abofour, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. The major occupation in that community is crop farming -- some people farm maize, groundnuts, etc. as a result of good fertile land they occupied. Comfort has been selling yams and bags of gari for almost eight years to support her family. She started this business with her mother when she was a young girl. She takes delivery of stock from farmers who provide her with a direct supply of yam and gari. Gari is produced from cassava. It can be eaten with beans, rice and sugar. Gari is mostly purchased by students.

Buying direct enables Comfort to avoid middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. With this loan of GH¢500, she hopes to restock her inventory and buy a bulk supply of yams and gari to serve her customers. This would enable her to save more to support her husband in taking care of their home. She also hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids in school. Comfort belongs to a village bank (loan group) called ‘Agnes.’

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of yams and bags of gari for retailing.

loans.name: Fanta  Traore

texts.fr:
Madame F.  Traoré est une femme mariée de cinquante trois (53) ans, mère de neuf (9) enfants qui vit dans une famille nucléaire dans la sous-préfecture de Selingué.
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, elle intégra le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursés ses trois prêts, elle est à son quatrième prêt individuel.
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter, 1400  kilogrammes de riz sur le marché de Selingué auprès des riziculteurs du casier rizicole.
Le riz est souvent fumé, parfois vendu sans aucune transformation  sur les marchés de Selingué et environs et de Bamako (capitale du Mali).
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 45.000  F CFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Ms. F. Traoré is a married women, 53 years of age, and the mother of nine children. She lives in a nuclear family in the sub-prefecture of Selingué. Concerned about increasing her working capital, she joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. After have correctly repaid her three loans, she is on her fourth individual loan, which she plans to use for buying 1,400 kg of rice from the Selingué market near the growers in their rice fields. Rice is often smoked, but sometimes sold unprocessed at all, in the Selingué marketplaces, in surrounding areas, and in Bamako, the capital of Mali.

She intends to realize an average monthly profit of 45,000 francs CFA that will be used to make loan payments and to help cover family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice for resale

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet F. is 50 years old. She is a married woman and a mother with grown children. But for now ,she is taking care of two of her grandchildren who are currently in school. She lives with her family at Abofour, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. For the last year, she has traded in silver and plastic materials like plates, buckets, bowls, cooking utensils etc. She sells every Thursday in the Abofour market and demand for her goods is booming. 

She is requesting a loan to augment her working capital and buy more stock of silver and plastic materials to sell. She believes the loan will enable her to raise more income to support her family. Janet belongs to a village bank called ‘Fear Not’. She also hope to receive GH¢500 to develop her business by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to support her husband with taking care of the home.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cooking utensils and plastics bowls.

loans.name: Comunidad Unida 5 & 6 Group

texts.en: Margarita G. M. is one of the members of group 6 in the "Comunidad Unida" (United Community) Bank of Hope. This loan is also being taken by group 5 in the same bank, for a total of 10 borrowers. These groups are located in Brisas del Ozama, a community located on the eastern part of Santo Domingo, very near the Ozama River, one of the largest in the country. During rainy season, this river is a serious threat to these people`s houses. Margarita sells clothes as a business. With her new loan she wants to increase her business even more. Elize hopes that she one day will be able to buy a nice house to live in. She is also very preoccupied about the future of her children. Please help us support these ladies` hard work. Thank you!

loans.use: purchase new merchandise to refurbish their businesses

loans.name: Akwasi

texts.en:
Akwasi B. S. is 52 years old. He is married and father of four children. Currently, two children are in school. He lives in his own house at Abofour, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Akwasi managed to build a two bed room house from the proceeds from his farm and sewing.

He has been sewing for the past thirty five years. He is a specialist in women's, gent's and kid's wear. His skills and designs are classic. He sews various kinds of styles that give his customers a new look, like kaba and slit, funeral clothes etc. Akwasi is also a farmer and he has been farming since childhood. He wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. and agro chemicals to spray his cocoa farm to increase his output and efficiency. He hopes to increase his savings to provide his children with quality education. 

Akwasi belongs to a village bank called ‘Fear Not’. He also hopes to receive GH¢1000 to develop his business by restocking his inventory and buy agro chemicals. This would enable him to save more to take care of the home.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata Traoré est une femme mariée de quarante huit (48) ans et mère de cinq (5)  enfants qui vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans une famille monogame dans le village de Dialakoroba (deuxième administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle fréquenta l’école jusqu’au lycée où elle  abandonna pour le mariage. Après elle bénéficia des formations en santé maternelle et infantile qui lui ont permis  de mieux connaître les médicaments afin de les commercialiser.
En vu de mieux fructifier  son activité elle a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso auprès de laquelle elle bénéficia de quatre prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) et trois prêts individuels. Elle est à son quatrième  individuel et tous ses prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, une importante quantité de produits pharmaceutiques au dépôt de la pharmacie populaire du Mali à Bamako une fois par mois pour les revendre au Centre de Santé de son village qu’elle-même a la responsabilité de la gestion de la pharmacie.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 110. 000  F CFA qui servira à payer l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré, age 48, is married and the mother of 5 children. She lives with her husband and her children in a monogamous family in the village of Dialakoroba (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She attended school up to high school, before abandoning her studies to get married. Afterwards, she was trained in healthcare for mother and child, which enabled her to get to know medications better in order to sell them. To bolster her business, she joined the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, from which she obtained 4 group loans (solidarity loans) and 3 individual loans. She's now seeking her fourth individual loan. All previous loans were repaid without problems. With this loan, she intends to buy every month large quantities of pharmaceutical products in Bamako, at the governmental pharmacy, in order to resell them in the health center of her village, where she's managing the pharmacy. She foresees an average monthly profit of XOF 110'000 (ca US$ 220), to be used to repay the loan and help with the family expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell medications

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Touré est une femme mariée de quarante sept (47) ans, mère de quatre enfants elle vit dans une famille monogame à Sélingué.
Oumou fait le commerce de céréales notamment celui du riz depuis des années.
Elle est en relation avec l’institution de microfinance de Soro Yiriwaso il y a cinq (5) ans. Elle bénéficia de cinq prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et de quatre prêts individuels. Elle est à son cinquième prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien dénoués
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt  2100  kilogrammes de riz  sur le marché de selingué et revendre dans les marchés de  Sélingué et de Bamako une fois par mois aux revendeurs.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 100. 000  F CFA qui servira à payer les frais scolaires des enfants et rembourser l’échéance du prêt 
Madame Oumou Touré désire avoir dans les jours à venir son magasin de céréales.
texts.en:
Mrs Oumou Touré, age 47, is married and the mother of four children. She lives in a monogamous family in Sélingué. Oumou has been selling cereals, especially rice, for years. She's been in contact with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso for 5 years. She obtained five solidarity loans (group loans) and four individual loans. She's now seeking her fifth individual loan, and all previous loans ended without problems. With this loan, she intends to by 2100 kilograms of rice at the Selingué market, in order to resell it at the markets in Sélingué and Bamako once a month to resellers. She foresees an average monthly profit of XOF 100'000 (ca US$ 200), to be used to pay the school expenses of her children, and to repay the loan. In the future, Mrs. Oumou Touré would like to open her own cereals store.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell sacks of rice

loans.name: Rubén

texts.es:
El Sr. Rubén vive en pareja con la Sra. María  hace 5 años con quien tiene un hijo de 2 años de edad. Él se dedica al cuidado y asesoramiento del control de suelo para la plantación de caña de azúcar, algodón, tomates y otros.

Rubén proviene de una familia de agricultores, hace 7 años que emigró de su ciudad natal Ybycuí para asentarse actualmente en la ciudad de Itá.

Comenta que le va muy en su trabajo, ya que gracias a ello ayuda a muchas personas para la siembra de productos hortícolas.

Desde muy joven se dedica a la agricultura y comenta que es lo que realmente le gusta hacer.

En esta oportunidad solicita un préstamo que destinará a la compra de insecticidas.
texts.en:
Rubén has lived with María, with whom he has a 2 year old son, for 5 years. He dedicates himself to the care and consultancy for the planting of sugarcane, cotton, tomatoes, and others. Rubén comes from a family of farmers. It has been 7 years since he migrated from his birth city, Ybycuí, to settle down in the city of Itá. He says that he is getting along very well in his work, given that thanks to him he helps many people in the sowing of horticulture products. Since he was very young, he has dedicated himself to agriculture and comments that it is really what he likes to do. In this opportunity he is asking for a loan that he will use to buy insecticides.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy insecticide

loans.name: Ramata

texts.fr:
Madame Ramata Sidibé est une femme divorcée de trente (30) ans qui est mère de deux (2) enfants. Elle réside dans la sous-préfecture de  Sélingué situé à 140  kilomètres de Bamako. 
Après son divorce elle quitta Bamako (capitale du Mali) pour rejoindre  son village natal Sélingué. Afin  de s’insérer dans la vie active elle décide d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après deux (2) prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) avec une association de son quartier, elle est à son premier prêt individuel avec lequel elle désire acheter 350  kilogrammes de pommes de terre, 60  kilogrammes d’oignons et 70  kilogrammes de céréales.
Elle s’approvisionne deux fois par mois sur les marchés de différents villages environnants et revend sur son étale au marché de Sélingué, au comptant en détail et à crédit à une clientèle généralement composée de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 60.000 FCFA qui servira à payer l’échéance du prêt et les frais scolaires de ses enfants.
Madame Ramata  Sidibé ambitionne ouvrir un magasin de vente en gros de céréales et tubercules.
texts.en:
Ms. Ramata Sidibé, age 30, is divorced and the mother of two. She resides in the sub-prefecture of Sélingué located 140 km from Bamako, the capital of Mali. After her divorce, she left Bamako to return to her native village, Sélingué. In order to be active in life, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. After two group loans (solidarity loans) with an association in her district, she is on her first individual loan, which she would like to use for buying: 350 kg of potatoes, 60 kg of onions, and 70 kg of grain. She gets her supplies twice a month at the different marketplaces of surrounding villages and resells the goods from her display at the Sélingué market. Sales are made retail, cash or credit accepted, to customers general composed of women.

She hopes to realize a monthly profit of 60,000 francs for making loan payments and for covering the schooling costs for her children. She has the ambition to open a store for selling grain and tubers wholesale.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy potatoes, onions, and grain
